awd_titl_txt: Research on the Development of An Assessment to Measure Kindergarten Children's Abilities to Reason Computationally With Mathematical Problem-Solving Skills
awd_abstract_narration:
Students are coming into contact with programming toys at a young age. There are claims that use of such toys can enhance problem solving skills, develop early computational thinking, and provide a context for putting mathematics understandings to work. This has yielded a number of commercial products that purportedly help children to realize those benefits. While many of these early childhood coding toys are fun and playful, research on their ability to truly support early computer science learning is needed. For such work to be possible, educators need assessments that measure integrated computational thinking for early childhood learners that can quantify learning that takes place with coding toys. However, such assessments do not yet exist. This is compounded by a lack of curricular units and learning modules for early childhood classrooms that integrate computation and mathematics and build upon what these toys are supposed to offer. The project is funded by the STEM+C Program, which seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within disciplinary STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school. 

In this STEM+C project, mathematics and computational thinking will be integrated in early childhood education. Using Evidence-Centered Design, the project will develop a theoretically-based, empirically-tested assessment to measure kindergarten children's abilities to reason computationally with mathematical problem solving skills (i.e., strategies and ways of thinking that aid their understanding and use of mathematical knowledge) in teachers' classrooms. The project will also develop modules for kindergarten instruction that encourage integrated computational thinking with mathematical problem solving. Recognizing that these are circular constraints, the project will involve the following four sequential steps: (1) operationalize early CT in kindergarten mathematics classrooms by identifying CT competencies; (2) develop curriculum involving a subset of current early childhood toys around the competencies; (3) develop an assessment to measure students' CT and mathematics competencies; and (4) conduct evaluation studies of the curriculum and assessment in kindergarten classrooms. Project deliverables include: a competency model of integrated computational thinking; an assessment that measures the competency model; and curriculum resources for teachers around the competency model that leverages toys and technologies intended for early childhood settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Children are coming into contact with programming toys at a young age. There are several commercial products that claim to help young children develop computer programming and problem-solving skills. These toys offer a variety of programming interfaces including tangible blocks, screen-based block programming, and hybrid interfaces that mix both tangible and screen-based. We expect that programming toys will continue to be manufactured, distributed, and brought into early childhood classrooms. While many of these early childhood programming toys are fun and playful, research on their ability to truly support early computer science learning is needed. In response to this need, this project studied the possibility of tangible coding toys in which children program a robot-based agent to move (see Figure 1) for fostering the integration of computer science and mathematics in early childhood classrooms, with an emphasis on kindergarten. 

This project impacted over 500 children. We conducted classroom studies and assessment pilots with over 300 children ages 4-8. We then conducted evidence of the validity, reliability, and fairness of a performance assessment with 272 children. Through this research, we identified several outcomes:  


We identified indicators for identifying children's thinking based on the mistakes that they make while programming these toys. Teachers can use these indicators to modify their instruction for meeting children at their current levels of skills and understanding. 


We identified that children use spatial thinking and mathematics knowledge to solve tasks with tangible programming toys including, code-to-movement correspondence, spatial orientation of the agent, rotation on a point, and linear units (see Figure 2). 


We identified robot design features that can afford mathematical concepts and skills, for example grid squares features afforded unit construction and stop in-between movement features afforded unit coordination.


We identified ways that social and emotional learning happens through learning to program, such as when children take on different roles to program and operate the robot or when children develop caring attitudes towards robots used for programming.


We found that— when the context for tangible programming is the classroom floor, and when children are free to move around to learn to program— it is important for teachers to notice how social dynamics may make it easier for some children to access valued materials and feel comfortable in the classroom. 


We found that programming toys are a great context for fostering computational thinking skills, a higher order skill that includes the ability to identify and solve problems. 


We found that design elements for programming toy tasks and instruction supported learning to program in Kindergarten, specifically, considerations for introductory lessons (e.g., focus on spatial code meaning), attention to skills and strategies within engaging challenges (e.g., tasks that encourage debugging situations), and leveraging robot toys’ design features for specific computational thinking and mathematics skills (e.g., program organizers for movement-code correspondence).


We found that evidence-centered design is a useful framework for developing both classroom formative assessments as well as a performance-based assessment of early childhood computational thinking. 


We found evidence of validity, reliability, and fairness of our performance assessment in a study with 272 children (girls = 138), between 47 and 101 months old (M = 78.5; SD = 10.8). The performance assessment tasks fit well to a two-parameter unidimensional Item Response Theory model (2PL IRT, see Na et al., 2024). The results of item analyses showed a high item discrimination (M = 2.26) and a moderate item difficulty (M = -.21), on average, with a high marginal reliability (rxx = .87). We conducted differential item functioning (DIF) to check if the items functioned equally for all children, regardless of their gender or age and did not find any evidence of bias. In terms of reliability, Cronbach’s alpha indicated high internal consistency (α = .91) and McDonald’s omega saturation (ω = .92).

Products

This project produced three products: an empirically informed cognitive model of early childhood computational thinking for the context of using tangible coding toys in early childhood settings (see Figure 2); a set of instructional activities and resources for early childhood teachers to use tangible coding toys in their classrooms, and a performance-based assessment aligned to our early childhood model that is unplugged and can be used across coding toys (see Figure 3).  The products from this project including the curricular tasks, provide a vehicle for engaging young children in foundational mathematics and spatial thinking skills that have implications for broadening participation in STEM. The shared resources also can help early childhood educator capacity.

 

More information can be found at cik.usu.edu
